001package com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.cielab;
002
003import com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.Color;
004import com.badlogic.gdx.math.MathUtils;
005import com.badlogic.gdx.utils.NumberUtils;
006import com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.FloatColors;
007import com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.Shaders;
008import com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.TrigTools;
009
010import java.util.Random;
011
012/**
013 * Contains code for manipulating colors as {@code int} and packed {@code float} values in the CIE L*A*B* color space.
014 * This is the old standard (and for some things, gold standard) of color spaces, introduced in 1976 and never fully
015 * superseded by a newer color space. A reason there are still newer color spaces being introduced is in part that
016 * existing color spaces, such as CIELAB, don't have sufficient performance for a given task, and this is an especially
017 * fair criticism of CIELAB -- it's slow. But, if you calculate new colors infrequently and do the heaviest conversions
018 * in a shader, this might not be noticeably different from Oklab or IPT_HQ. This package emphasizes quality over speed,
019 * so some calculations that are approximated in Oklab and IPT_HQ are performed rigorously here.
020 * <br>
021 * The CIE L*A*B* color space has 3 channels, L, A, and B, each gamma-corrected (which is why an asterisk is added).
022 * L is lightness, A is a chroma axis that is (roughly) cyan-vs.-red, and B is a chroma axis that is (roughly)
023 * blue-vs.-yellow. This is the same in concept as Oklab, but Oklab is skewed somewhat so high B there is more orange
024 * than yellow; it's somewhat hard to accurately produce yellow in Oklab. This also has an alpha channel in each color,
025 * which acts like it does in every other color space package here (multiplicative alpha, higher is more opaque).
026 */
027public class ColorTools {
028    /**
029     * No need to instantiate.
030     */
031    private ColorTools(){
032    }
033    /**
034     * Gets a packed float representation of a color given as 4 float components, here, L (luminance or lightness), A
035     * (a chromatic component ranging from cyan to red), B (a chromatic component ranging from blue to yellow), and
036     * alpha (or opacity). As long as you use a batch with {@link Shaders#fragmentShaderCielab} as its shader, colors
037     * passed with {@link com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.Batch#setPackedColor(float)} will be interpreted as CIELAB. L
038     * should be between 0 and 1, inclusive, with 0 used for very dark colors (almost only black), and 1 used for very
039     * light colors (almost only white). A and B range from 0.0 to 1.0, with grayscale results when both are about 0.5.
040     * There's some aesthetic value in changing just one chroma value. When A is high and B is low, the color is more
041     * purple/magenta, when both are low it is more bluish, when B is high and A is low, the color tends to be greenish,
042     * and when both are high it tends to be orange. When A and B are both near 0.5f, the color is closer to gray.
043     * Alpha is the multiplicative opacity of the color, and acts like RGBA's alpha.
044     *
045     * @param l     0f to 1f, lightness or L component of CIELAB, with 0.5f meaning "no change" and 1f brightening
046     * @param a     0f to 1f, A component of CIELAB, with 1f more orange, red, or magenta
047     * @param b     0f to 1f, B component of CIELAB, with 1f more green, yellow, or red
048     * @param alpha 0f to 1f, 0f makes the color transparent and 1f makes it opaque
049     * @return a float encoding a color with the given properties
050     */
051    public static float cielab(float l, float a, float b, float alpha) {
052        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (alpha * 255.999f) << 24 & 0xFE000000) | ((int) (b * 255.999f) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
053                | ((int) (a * 255.999f) << 8 & 0xFF00) | ((int) (l * 255.999f) & 0xFF));
054    }
055    /**
056     * Gets a packed float representation of a color given as 4 float components, L, A, B, and alpha, with each
057     * component clamped to the 0f to 1f range before being entered into the packed float color. This is only different
058     * from {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)} in that it clamps each component. It still permits out-of-gamut
059     * colors to be stored, but as long as the rendering code (such as a shader or ColorfulBatch) does its own
060     * validation or correction of colors, then having out-of-gamut colors shouldn't be a problem.
061     *
062     * @see #cielab(float, float, float, float) This uses the same definitions for L, A, B, and alpha as cielab().
063     * @param l     0f to 1f, lightness or L component of CIELAB, with 0.5f meaning "no change" and 1f brightening
064     * @param a     0f to 1f, A component of CIELAB, with 1f more orange, red, or magenta
065     * @param b     0f to 1f, B component of CIELAB, with 1f more green, yellow, or red
066     * @param alpha 0f to 1f, 0f makes the color transparent and 1f makes it opaque
067     * @return a float encoding a color with the given properties
068     */
069    public static float clamp(float l, float a, float b, float alpha) {
070        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat((Math.min(Math.max((int) (alpha * 127.999f), 0), 127) << 25)
071                | (Math.min(Math.max((int) (b * 255.999f), 0), 255) << 16)
072                | (Math.min(Math.max((int) (a * 255.999f), 0), 255) << 8)
073                | (Math.min(Math.max((int) (l * 255.999f), 0), 255))
074        );
075    }
076
077
078    /**
079     * An approximation of the cube-root function for float inputs and outputs.
080     * This can be about twice as fast as {@link Math#cbrt(double)}. This
081     * version does not tolerate negative inputs, because in the narrow use
082     * case it has in this class, it never is given negative inputs.
083     * <br>
084     * Has very low relative error (less than 1E-9) when inputs are uniformly
085     * distributed between 0 and 512, and absolute mean error of less than
086     * 1E-6 in the same scenario. Uses a bit-twiddling method similar to one
087     * presented in Hacker's Delight and also used in early 3D graphics (see
088     * https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fast_inverse_square_root for more, but
089     * this code approximates cbrt(x) and not 1/sqrt(x)). This specific code
090     * was originally by Marc B. Reynolds, posted in his "Stand-alone-junk"
091     * repo: https://github.com/Marc-B-Reynolds/Stand-alone-junk/blob/master/src/Posts/ballcube.c#L182-L197 .
092     * It's worth noting that while hardware instructions for finding the
093     * square root of a float have gotten extremely fast, the same is not
094     * true for the cube root (which has to allow negative inputs), so while
095     * the bit-twiddling inverse square root is no longer a beneficial
096     * optimization on current hardware, this does seem to help.
097     * <br>
098     * This is used when converting from RGB to CIELAB, as an intermediate step.
099     * @param x any non-negative finite float to find the cube root of
100     * @return the cube root of x, approximated
101     */
102    private static float cbrtPositive(float x) {
103        int ix = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(x);
104        final float x0 = x;
105        ix = (ix>>>2) + (ix>>>4);
106        ix += (ix>>>4);
107        ix += (ix>>>8) + 0x2A5137A0;
108        x  = NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(ix);
109        x  = 0.33333334f*(2f * x + x0/(x*x));
110        x  = 0.33333334f*(2f * x + x0/(x*x));
111        return x;
112    }
113
114    /**
115     * Used when given non-linear sRGB inputs to make them linear, using an exact gamma of 2.4 and accounting for the
116     * darkest colors with a different formula.
117     * @param component any non-linear channel of a color, to be made linear
118     * @return a linear version of component
119     */
120    private static float forwardGamma(final float component) {
121        return component < 0.04045f ? component * (1f/12.92f) : (float)Math.pow((component + 0.055f) * (1f/1.055f), 2.4f);
122    }
123
124    /**
125     * Used to return from a linear, gamma-corrected input to an sRGB, non-linear output, using an exact gamma of 2.4
126     * and accounting for the darkest colors with a different formula.
127     * @param component a linear channel of a color, to be made non-linear
128     * @return a non-linear version of component
129     */
130    private static float reverseGamma(final float component) {
131        return component < 0.0031308f ? component * 12.92f : (float)Math.pow(component, 1f/2.4f) * 1.055f - 0.055f;
132    }
133
134    private static float forwardXYZ(final float t) {
135        return (t < 0.00885645f) ? 7.787037f * t + 0.139731f : cbrtPositive(t);
136    }
137
138    private static float reverseXYZ(final float t) {
139        return (t < 0.20689655f) ? 0.1284185f * (t - 0.139731f) : t * t * t;
140    }
141
142    /**
143     * Converts a packed float color in the format produced by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)} to an RGBA8888 int.
144     * This format of int can be used with Pixmap and in some other places in libGDX.
145     * @param packed a packed float color, as produced by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}
146     * @return an RGBA8888 int color
147     */
148    public static int toRGBA8888(final float packed)
149    {
150        final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
151        final float L = (1f/1.16f)*((decoded & 0xff) / 255f + 0.16f);
152        final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.2f / 127.5f);
153        final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.5f / 127.5f);
154        final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A);
155        final float y = reverseXYZ(L);
156        final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B);
157        final int r = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
158        final int g = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
159        final int b = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
160        return r << 24 | g << 16 | b << 8 | (decoded & 0xfe000000) >>> 24 | decoded >>> 31;
161    }
162
163    /**
164     * Converts a packed float color in the format produced by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}
165     * to a packed float in ABGR8888 format.
166     * This format of float can be used with the standard SpriteBatch and in some other places in libGDX.
167     * @param packed a packed float color, as produced by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}
168     * @return a packed float color as ABGR8888
169     */
170    public static float toRGBA(final float packed)
171    {
172        final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
173        final float L = (1f/1.16f)*((decoded & 0xff) / 255f + 0.16f);
174        final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.2f / 127.5f);
175        final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.5f / 127.5f);
176        final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A);
177        final float y = reverseXYZ(L);
178        final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B);
179        final int r = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
180        final int g = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
181        final int b = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
182        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(r | g << 8 | b << 16 | (decoded & 0xfe000000));
183    }
184
185    /**
186     * Writes a CIELAB-format packed float color (the format produced by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)})
187     * into an RGBA8888 Color as used by libGDX (called {@code editing}).
188     * @param editing a libGDX color that will be filled in-place with an RGBA conversion of {@code packed}
189     * @param packed a packed float color, as produced by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}
190     * @return an RGBA8888 int color
191     */
192    public static Color toColor(Color editing, final float packed)
193    {
194        final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
195        final float L = (1f/1.16f)*((decoded & 0xff) / 255f + 0.16f);
196//        final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (1f / 127.5f);
197//        final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (1f / 127.5f);
198        final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.2f / 127.5f);
199        final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.5f / 127.5f);
200        final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A);
201        final float y = reverseXYZ(L);
202        final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B);
203        editing.r = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z, 0f), 1f));
204        editing.g = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z, 0f), 1f));
205        editing.b = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z, 0f), 1f));
206        editing.a = (decoded >>> 25) * 0x1.020408p-7f; // this is 1/127 as a float
207        return editing.clamp();
208    }
209
210    /**
211     * Writes a CIELAB-format packed float color (the format produced by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)})
212     * into a CIELAB-format Color called {@code editing}. This is mostly useful if the rest of your application expects
213     * colors in CIELAB format, such as because you use {@link Shaders#fragmentShaderCielab} or {@link ColorfulBatch}.
214     * <br>
215     * Internally, this simply calls {@link Color#abgr8888ToColor(Color, float)} and returns the edited Color.
216     * @param editing a libGDX Color that will be filled in-place with the color {@code cielab}, unchanged from its color space
217     * @param cielab a packed float color, as produced by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}
218     * @return an RGBA8888 int color
219     */
220    public static Color toCIELABColor(Color editing, final float cielab){
221        Color.abgr8888ToColor(editing, cielab);
222        return editing;
223    }
224
225    /**
226     * Takes a color encoded as an RGBA8888 int and converts to a packed float in the CIELAB format this uses.
227     * @param rgba an int with the channels (in order) red, green, blue, alpha; should have 8 bits per channel
228     * @return a packed float as CIELAB, which this class can use
229     */
230    public static float fromRGBA8888(final int rgba) {
231        final float r = forwardGamma((rgba >>> 24) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
232        final float g = forwardGamma((rgba >>> 16 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
233        final float b = forwardGamma((rgba >>> 8 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
234
235        final float x = forwardXYZ(0.4124564f * r  + 0.3575761f * g + 0.1804375f * b);
236        final float y = forwardXYZ(0.2126729f * r  + 0.7151522f * g + 0.0721750f * b);
237        final float z = forwardXYZ(0.0193339f * r  + 0.1191920f * g + 0.9503041f * b);
238
239        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
240                          Math.min(Math.max((int)((1.16f*y - 0.16f) * 255.999f    ), 0), 255)
241                        | Math.min(Math.max((int)((x - y) * (127.999f * 5f) + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 8
242                        | Math.min(Math.max((int)((y - z) * (127.999f * 2f) + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 16
243                        | (rgba & 0xFE) << 24);
244    }
245
246    /**
247     * Takes a color encoded as an ABGR packed float and converts to a packed float in the CIELAB format this uses.
248     * @param packed a packed float in ABGR8888 format, with A in the MSB and R in the LSB
249     * @return a packed float as CIELAB, which this class can use
250     */
251    public static float fromRGBA(final float packed) {
252        final int abgr = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
253        final float r = forwardGamma((abgr & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
254        final float g = forwardGamma((abgr >>> 8 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
255        final float b = forwardGamma((abgr >>> 16 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
256
257        final float x = forwardXYZ(0.4124564f * r + 0.3575761f * g + 0.1804375f * b);
258        final float y = forwardXYZ(0.2126729f * r + 0.7151522f * g + 0.0721750f * b);
259        final float z = forwardXYZ(0.0193339f * r + 0.1191920f * g + 0.9503041f * b);
260
261        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
262                          Math.min(Math.max((int)((1.16f*y - 0.16f) * 255.999f    ), 0), 255)
263                        | Math.min(Math.max((int)(((x - y)) * (127.999f * 5f) + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 8
264                        | Math.min(Math.max((int)(((y - z)) * (127.999f * 2f) + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 16
265                        | (abgr & 0xFE000000));
266    }
267
268    /**
269     * Takes a libGDX Color that uses RGBA8888 channels and converts to a packed float in the CIELAB format this uses.
270     * @param color a libGDX RGBA8888 Color
271     * @return a packed float as CIELAB, which this class can use
272     */
273    public static float fromColor(final Color color) {
274        final float r = forwardGamma(color.r);
275        final float g = forwardGamma(color.g);
276        final float b = forwardGamma(color.b);
277        final float x = forwardXYZ(0.4124564f * r + 0.3575761f * g + 0.1804375f * b);
278        final float y = forwardXYZ(0.2126729f * r + 0.7151522f * g + 0.0721750f * b);
279        final float z = forwardXYZ(0.0193339f * r + 0.1191920f * g + 0.9503041f * b);
280        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
281                          Math.min(Math.max((int)((1.16f*y - 0.16f) * 255.999f    ), 0), 255)
282                        | Math.min(Math.max((int)(((x - y)) * (127.999f * 5f) + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 8
283                        | Math.min(Math.max((int)(((y - z)) * (127.999f * 2f) + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 16
284                        | ((int)(color.a * 255f) << 24 & 0xFE000000));
285    }
286
287    /**
288     * Takes RGBA components from 0.0 to 1.0 each and converts to a packed float in the CIELAB format this uses.
289     * @param r red, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
290     * @param g green, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
291     * @param b blue, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
292     * @param a alpha, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
293     * @return a packed float as CIELAB, which this class can use
294     */
295    public static float fromRGBA(float r, float g, float b, final float a) {
296        r = forwardGamma(r);
297        g = forwardGamma(g);
298        b = forwardGamma(b);
299        final float x = forwardXYZ(0.4124564f * r + 0.3575761f * g + 0.1804375f * b);
300        final float y = forwardXYZ(0.2126729f * r + 0.7151522f * g + 0.0721750f * b);
301        final float z = forwardXYZ(0.0193339f * r + 0.1191920f * g + 0.9503041f * b);
302        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
303                          Math.min(Math.max((int)((1.16f*y - 0.16f) * 255.999f    ), 0), 255)
304                        | Math.min(Math.max((int)(((x - y)) * (127.999f * 5f) + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 8
305                        | Math.min(Math.max((int)(((y - z)) * (127.999f * 2f) + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 16
306                        | ((int)(a * 255f) << 24 & 0xFE000000));
307    }
308
309        /**
310         * Gets the red channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
311         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}
312         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the red channel value of the given encoded color
313         */
314        public static int redInt(final float encoded)
315        {
316        final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
317        final float L = (1f/1.16f)*((decoded & 0xff) / 255f + 0.16f);
318        final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) *  (0.2f / 127.5f);
319        final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.5f / 127.5f);
320        final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A);
321        final float y = reverseXYZ(L);
322        final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B);
323        return (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
324        }
325
326        /**
327         * Gets the green channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
328         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}
329         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the green channel value of the given encoded color
330         */
331        public static int greenInt(final float encoded)
332        {
333        final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
334        final float L = (1f/1.16f)*((decoded & 0xff) / 255f + 0.16f);
335        final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) *  (0.2f / 127.5f);
336        final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.5f / 127.5f);
337        final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A);
338        final float y = reverseXYZ(L);
339        final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B);
340        return (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
341        }
342
343        /**
344         * Gets the blue channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
345         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}
346         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the blue channel value of the given encoded color
347         */
348        public static int blueInt(final float encoded)
349        {
350        final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
351        final float L = (1f/1.16f)*((decoded & 0xff) / 255f + 0.16f);
352        final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) *  (0.2f / 127.5f);
353        final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.5f / 127.5f);
354        final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A);
355        final float y = reverseXYZ(L);
356        final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B);
357        return (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
358        }
359
360        /**
361         * Gets the alpha channel value of the given encoded color, as an even int ranging from 0 to 254, inclusive. Because
362         * of how alpha is stored in libGDX, no odd-number values are possible for alpha.
363         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}
364         * @return an even int from 0 to 254, inclusive, representing the alpha channel value of the given encoded color
365         */
366        public static int alphaInt(final float encoded)
367        {
368                return (NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xfe000000) >>> 24;
369        }
370    /**
371     * Gets the red channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
372     * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}
373     * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the red channel value of the given encoded color
374     */
375    public static float red(final float encoded)
376    {
377        final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
378        final float L = (1f/1.16f)*((decoded & 0xff) / 255f + 0.16f);
379        final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) *  (0.2f / 127.5f);
380        final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.5f / 127.5f);
381        final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A);
382        final float y = reverseXYZ(L);
383        final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B);
384        return reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z, 0f), 1f));
385    }
386
387    /**
388     * Gets the green channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
389     * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}
390     * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the green channel value of the given encoded color
391     */
392    public static float green(final float encoded)
393    {
394        final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
395        final float L = (1f/1.16f)*((decoded & 0xff) / 255f + 0.16f);
396        final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) *  (0.2f / 127.5f);
397        final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.5f / 127.5f);
398        final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A);
399        final float y = reverseXYZ(L);
400        final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B);
401        return reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z, 0f), 1f));
402    }
403
404    /**
405     * Gets the blue channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
406     * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}
407     * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the blue channel value of the given encoded color
408     */
409    public static float blue(final float encoded)
410    {
411        final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
412        final float L = (1f/1.16f)*((decoded & 0xff) / 255f + 0.16f);
413        final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) *  (0.2f / 127.5f);
414        final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.5f / 127.5f);
415        final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A);
416        final float y = reverseXYZ(L);
417        final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B);
418        return reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z, 0f), 1f));
419    }
420
421    /**
422     * Gets the alpha channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
423     * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}
424     * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the alpha channel value of the given encoded color
425     */
426    public static float alpha(final float encoded)
427    {
428        return ((NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xfe000000) >>> 24) * 0x1.020408p-8f;
429    }
430
431
432    /**
433     * Gets the "chroma" or "colorfulness" of a given CIELAB color. Chroma is similar to saturation in that grayscale
434     * values have 0 saturation and 0 chroma, while brighter colors have high saturation and chroma. The difference is
435     * that colors that are perceptually more-colorful have higher chroma than colors that are perceptually
436     * less-colorful, regardless of hue, whereas saturation changes its meaning depending on the hue and lightness. That
437     * is, the most saturated color for a given hue and lightness always has a saturation of 1, but if that color
438     * isn't perceptually very colorful (as is the case for very dark and very light colors), it will have a chroma that
439     * is much lower than the maximum. The result of this method can't be negative, grayscale values have very close to
440     * 0 chroma, and the most colorful value (a shade of purple) should have 1.26365817 chroma.
441     * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}
442     * @return a float between 0.0f and 1.26365817 that represents how colorful the given value is
443     */
444    public static float chroma(final float encoded) {
445        final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
446        final float a = ((decoded >>> 7 & 0x1FE) - 255) / 255f;
447        final float b = ((decoded >>> 15 & 0x1FE) - 255) / 255f;
448        return (float) Math.sqrt(a * a + b * b);
449    }
450    /**
451     * Given a hue and lightness, this gets the (very approximate) maximum chroma possible for that hue-lightness
452     * combination, using CIELAB's versions of lightness and hue (not HSL). This is useful to know the bounds of
453     * {@link #chroma(float)}. This should be no greater than 1.26365817f . Note that this version of chromaLimit() is
454     * much slower than Oklab's version, because this has to go to much greater lengths to become accurate.
455     * @param hue the hue, typically between 0.0f and 1.0f, to look up
456     * @param lightness the lightness, clamped between 0.0f and 1.0f, to look up
457     * @return the maximum possible chroma for the given hue and lightness, between 0.0f and 1.26365817f
458     */
459    public static float chromaLimit(final float hue, final float lightness) {
460        final float h = hue - MathUtils.floor(hue);
461        final float L = (1f/1.16f)*(lightness + 0.16f);
462        final float A = TrigTools.cos_(h) * (1.26365817f);
463        final float B = TrigTools.sin_(h) * (1.26365817f);
464        final float y = reverseXYZ(L);
465        float A2 = A, B2 = B;
466        for (int attempt = 127; attempt >= 0; attempt--) {
467            final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A2);
468            final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B2);
469            final float r = reverseGamma(+3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z);
470            final float g = reverseGamma(-0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z);
471            final float b = reverseGamma(+0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z);
472            if(r >= 0f && r <= 1f && g >= 0f && g <= 1f && b >= 0f && b <= 1f)
473                break;
474            final float progress = attempt * 0x1p-7f;
475            A2 = (A * progress);
476            B2 = (B * progress);
477        }
478        return (float) Math.sqrt(A2 * A2 + B2 * B2);
479    }
480    /**
481     * Gets the color with the same L as the CIELAB color stored in the given packed float, but the furthest A
482     * B from gray possible for that lightness while keeping the same hue as the given color. This is very
483     * similar to calling {@link #enrich(float, float)} with a very large {@code change} value.
484     * @param packed a packed float color in CIELAB format; does not need to be in-gamut
485     * @return the color that is as far from grayscale as this can get while keeping the L and hue of packed
486     * @see #limitToGamut(float) You can use limitToGamut() if you only want max saturation for out-of-gamut colors.
487     */
488    public static float maximizeSaturation(final float packed) {
489        final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
490        final float lightness = (decoded & 255) / 255f;
491        final float h = TrigTools.atan2_(((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f), ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f));
492        final float L = (1f/1.16f)*(lightness + 0.16f);
493        final float A = TrigTools.cos_(h) * 1.26365817f * 0.2f;
494        final float B = TrigTools.sin_(h) * 1.26365817f * 0.5f;
495        final float y = reverseXYZ(L);
496        float A2 = A, B2 = B;
497        for (int attempt = 127; attempt >= 0; attempt--) {
498            final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A2);
499            final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B2);
500            final float r = reverseGamma(+3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z);
501            final float g = reverseGamma(-0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z);
502            final float b = reverseGamma(+0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z);
503            if(r >= 0f && r <= 1f && g >= 0f && g <= 1f && b >= 0f && b <= 1f)
504                break;
505            final float progress = attempt * 0x1p-7f;
506            A2 = (A * progress);
507            B2 = (B * progress);
508        }
509        return cielab(lightness, A2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, B2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, (decoded >>> 25) / 127f);
510    }
511    /**
512     * Gets the color with the same L as the CIELAB color stored in the given packed float, but the furthest A
513     * B from gray possible for that lightness while keeping the same hue as the given color. This is very
514     * similar to calling {@link #enrich(float, float)} with a very large {@code change} value.
515     * @param L lightness component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
516     * @param A green-to-red chromatic component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
517     * @param B blue-to-yellow chromatic component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
518     * @param alpha alpha component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
519     * @return the color that is as far from grayscale as this can get while keeping the L and hue of packed
520     * @see #limitToGamut(float, float, float, float) You can use limitToGamut() if you only want max saturation
521     * for out-of-gamut colors.
522     */
523    public static float maximizeSaturation(float L, float A, float B, float alpha) {
524        L = Math.min(Math.max(L, 0f), 1f);
525        A = Math.min(Math.max(A, 0f), 1f);
526        B = Math.min(Math.max(B, 0f), 1f);
527        alpha = Math.min(Math.max(alpha, 0f), 1f);
528        final float h = TrigTools.atan2_(B - 0.5f, A - 0.5f);
529        final float L0 = (1f/1.16f)*(L + 0.16f);
530        final float A0 = TrigTools.cos_(h) * 1.26365817f;
531        final float B0 = TrigTools.sin_(h) * 1.26365817f;
532        final float y = reverseXYZ(L0);
533        float A2 = A0, B2 = B0;
534        for (int attempt = 127; attempt >= 0; attempt--) {
535            final float x = reverseXYZ(L0 + A2);
536            final float z = reverseXYZ(L0 - B2);
537            final float r = reverseGamma(+3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z);
538            final float g = reverseGamma(-0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z);
539            final float b = reverseGamma(+0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z);
540            if(r >= 0f && r <= 1f && g >= 0f && g <= 1f && b >= 0f && b <= 1f)
541                break;
542            final float progress = attempt * 0x1p-7f;
543            A2 = (A0 * progress);
544            B2 = (B0 * progress);
545        }
546        return cielab(L, A2, B2, alpha);
547    }
548
549    /**
550     * Gets the hue of the given CIELAB float color, but as CIELAB understands hue rather than how HSL does.
551     * This is different from {@link #hue(float)}, which uses HSL. This gives a float between 0 (inclusive)
552     * and 1 (exclusive).
553     *
554     * @param packed a packed CIELAB float color
555     * @return a float between 0 (inclusive) and 1 (exclusive) that represents hue in the CIELAB color space
556     */
557    public static float cielabHue(final float packed) {
558        final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
559        final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) *  (0.2f / 127.5f);
560        final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.5f / 127.5f);
561        return TrigTools.atan2_(B, A);
562    }
563
564    /**
565     * Gets the saturation of the given CIELAB float color, but as CIELAB understands saturation rather than how HSL
566     * does. Saturation here is a fraction of the chroma limit (see {@link #chromaLimit(float, float)}) for a given hue
567     * and lightness, and is between 0 and 1. This gives a float between 0 (inclusive) and 1 (inclusive).
568     *
569     * @param packed a packed CIELAB float color
570     * @return a float between 0 (inclusive) and 1 (inclusive) that represents saturation in the CIELAB color space
571     */
572    public static float cielabSaturation(final float packed) {
573        final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
574        final float L = (1f/1.16f)*(((decoded & 0xff) / 255f) + 0.16f);
575        final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) *  (0.2f / 127.5f);
576        final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.5f / 127.5f);
577        final float h = TrigTools.atan2_(B, A);
578        final float L0 = (1f/1.16f)*(L + 0.16f);
579        final float A0 = TrigTools.cos_(h) * 1.26365817f;
580        final float B0 = TrigTools.sin_(h) * 1.26365817f;
581        final float y = reverseXYZ(L0);
582        float A2 = A0, B2 = B0;
583        for (int attempt = 127; attempt >= 0; attempt--) {
584            final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A2);
585            final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B2);
586            final float r = reverseGamma(+3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z);
587            final float g = reverseGamma(-0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z);
588            final float b = reverseGamma(+0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z);
589            if(r >= 0f && r <= 1f && g >= 0f && g <= 1f && b >= 0f && b <= 1f)
590                break;
591            final float progress = attempt * 0x1p-7f;
592            A2 = (A0 * progress);
593            B2 = (B0 * progress);
594        }
595        final float dist = (float) Math.sqrt(A2 * A2 + B2 * B2);
596        return (float) Math.sqrt(A * A + B * B) / dist;
597    }
598    /**
599     * Gets the lightness of the given CIELAB float color, but as CIELAB understands lightness rather than how HSL does.
600     * This is different from {@link #lightness(float)}, which uses HSL. This gives a float between 0 (inclusive)
601     * and 1 (inclusive).
602     * <br>
603     * This is the same as {@link #channelL(float)}.
604     *
605     * @param packed a packed CIELAB float color
606     * @return a float between 0 (inclusive) and 1 (inclusive) that represents lightness in the CIELAB color space
607     */
608    public static float cielabLightness(final float packed){
609        return (NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed) & 0xff) / 255f;
610    }
611
612    /**
613     * A different way to specify a CIELAB color, using hue, saturation, lightness, and alpha like a normal HSL(A) color
614     * but calculating them directly in the CIELAB color space. This is more efficient than
615     * {@link #floatGetHSL(float, float, float, float)}. You may prefer using
616     * {@link #cielabByHCL(float, float, float, float)}, which takes an absolute chroma as opposed to the saturation
617     * here (which is a fraction of the maximum chroma).
618     * <br>
619     * Note that this takes a different value for its {@code hue} that the method {@link #hue(float)} produces, just
620     * like its {@code saturation} and the method {@link #saturation(float)}, and {@code lightness} and the method
621     * {@link #lightness(float)}. The hue is just distributed differently, and the lightness should be equivalent to
622     * {@link #channelL(float)}, but the saturation here refers to what fraction the chroma should be of the maximum
623     * chroma for the given hue and lightness. You can use {@link #cielabHue(float)}, {@link #cielabSaturation(float)},
624     * and {@link #cielabLightness(float)} to get the hue, saturation, and lightness values from an existing color that
625     * this will understand ({@link #alpha(float)} too). This method is likely to be significantly slower than
626     * {@link #cielabByHCL(float, float, float, float)} because this needs to calculate the gamut.
627     * @param hue between 0 and 1, usually, but this will automatically wrap if too high or too low
628     * @param saturation will be clamped between 0 and 1
629     * @param lightness will be clamped between 0 and 1
630     * @param alpha will be clamped between 0 and 1
631     * @return a packed CIELAB float color that tries to match the requested hue, saturation, and lightness
632     */
633    public static float cielabByHSL(float hue, float saturation, float lightness, float alpha) {
634        lightness = Math.min(Math.max(lightness, 0f), 1f);
635        saturation = Math.min(Math.max(saturation, 0f), 1f);
636        hue -= MathUtils.floor(hue);
637        alpha = Math.min(Math.max(alpha, 0f), 1f);
638        final float L = (1f/1.16f)*(lightness + 0.16f);
639        final float L0 = (1f/1.16f)*(L + 0.16f);
640        final float cos = TrigTools.cos_(hue);
641        final float sin = TrigTools.sin_(hue);
642        final float A0 = cos * 1.26365817f * 0.2f;
643        final float B0 = sin * 1.26365817f * 0.5f;
644        final float y = reverseXYZ(L0);
645        float A2 = A0, B2 = B0;
646        for (int attempt = 127; attempt >= 0; attempt--) {
647            final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A2);
648            final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B2);
649            final float r = reverseGamma(+3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z);
650            final float g = reverseGamma(-0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z);
651            final float b = reverseGamma(+0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z);
652            if(r >= 0f && r <= 1f && g >= 0f && g <= 1f && b >= 0f && b <= 1f)
653                break;
654            final float progress = attempt * 0x1p-7f;
655            A2 = (A0 * progress);
656            B2 = (B0 * progress);
657        }
658        final float dist = (float) Math.sqrt(A2 * A2 + B2 * B2) * saturation;
659        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
660                (int) (alpha * 127.999f) << 25 |
661                        Math.min(Math.max((int) (sin * dist + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 16 |
662                        Math.min(Math.max((int) (cos * dist + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 8 |
663                        (int) (lightness * 255.999f));
664    }
665
666    /**
667     * A different way to specify a CIELAB color, using hue, chroma, lightness, and alpha something like a normal HSL(A)
668     * color but calculating them directly in the CIELAB color space. This has you specify the desired chroma directly,
669     * as obtainable with {@link #chroma(float)}, rather than the saturation, which is a fraction of the maximum chroma
670     * (saturation is what {@link #cielabByHSL(float, float, float, float)} uses). Note that this takes a different
671     * value for its {@code hue} that the method {@link #hue(float)} produces, just like {@code lightness} and the
672     * method {@link #lightness(float)}. The hue is just distributed differently, and the lightness should be equivalent
673     * to {@link #channelL(float)}. If you use this to get two colors with the same chroma and lightness, but different
674     * hue, then the resulting colors should have similar colorfulness unless one or both chroma values exceeded the
675     * gamut limit (you can get this limit with {@link #chromaLimit(float, float)}). If a chroma value given is greater
676     * than the chroma limit, this clamps chroma to that limit. You can use {@link #cielabHue(float)},
677     * {@link #chroma(float)}, and {@link #cielabLightness(float)} to get the hue, chroma, and lightness values from an
678     * existing color that this will understand ({@link #alpha(float)} too). This method should be significantly faster
679     * than {@link #cielabByHSL(float, float, float, float)} because it doesn't need to calculate the gamut.
680     * @param hue between 0 and 1, usually, but this will automatically wrap if too high or too low
681     * @param chroma will be clamped between 0 and the maximum chroma possible for the given hue and lightness
682     * @param lightness will be clamped between 0 and 1
683     * @param alpha will be clamped between 0 and 1
684     * @return a packed CIELAB float color that tries to match the requested hue, chroma, and lightness
685     */
686    public static float cielabByHCL(float hue, float chroma, float lightness, float alpha) {
687        lightness = Math.min(Math.max(lightness, 0f), 1f);
688        chroma = Math.max(chroma, 0f) * 127.5f;
689        hue -= MathUtils.floor(hue);
690        alpha = Math.min(Math.max(alpha, 0f), 1f);
691        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
692                (int) (alpha * 127.999f) << 25 |
693                        Math.min(Math.max((int) (TrigTools.sin_(hue) /* * 2f */ * chroma + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 16 |
694                        Math.min(Math.max((int) (TrigTools.cos_(hue) /* * 5f */ * chroma + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 8 |
695                        (int) (lightness * 255.999f));
696    }
697
698    /**
699     * Gets a color as a CIELAB packed float given floats representing hue, saturation, lightness, and opacity.
700     * All parameters should normally be between 0 and 1 inclusive, though any hue is tolerated (precision loss may
701     * affect the color if the hue is too large). A hue of 0 is red, progressively higher hue values go to orange,
702     * yellow, green, blue, and purple before wrapping around to red as it approaches 1. A saturation of 0 is grayscale,
703     * a saturation of 1 is brightly colored, and values close to 1 will usually appear more distinct than values close
704     * to 0, especially if the hue is different. A lightness of 0.001f or less is always black (also using a shortcut if
705     * this is the case, respecting opacity), while a lightness of 1f is white. Very bright colors are mostly in a band
706     * of high-saturation where lightness is 0.5f.
707     *
708     * @param hue        0f to 1f, color wheel position
709     * @param saturation 0f to 1f, 0f is grayscale and 1f is brightly colored
710     * @param lightness  0f to 1f, 0f is black and 1f is white
711     * @param opacity    0f to 1f, 0f is fully transparent and 1f is opaque
712     * @return a CIELAB float encoding a color with the given properties
713     */
714    public static float floatGetHSL(float hue, float saturation, float lightness, float opacity) {
715        if (lightness <= 0.001f) {
716            return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat((((int) (opacity * 255f) << 24) & 0xFE000000) | 0x7F7F00);
717        } else {
718            return fromRGBA(FloatColors.hsl2rgb(hue, saturation, lightness, opacity));
719        }
720    }
721
722    /**
723     * Gets the saturation of the given encoded color as HSL would calculate it, as a float ranging from 0.0f to 1.0f,
724     * inclusive. This is different from {@link #chroma(float)}; see that method's documentation for details.
725     *
726     * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}
727     * @return the saturation of the color from 0.0 (a grayscale color; inclusive) to 1.0 (a bright color, inclusive)
728     */
729    public static float saturation(final float encoded) {
730        final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
731        final float L = (1f/1.16f)*((decoded & 0xff) / 255f + 0.16f);
732        if(Math.abs(L - 0.5) > 0.495f) return 0f;
733        final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) *  (0.2f / 127.5f);
734        final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.5f / 127.5f);
735        final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A);
736        final float y = reverseXYZ(L);
737        final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B);
738        final float r = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z, 0f), 1f));
739        final float g = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z, 0f), 1f));
740        final float b = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z, 0f), 1f));
741        float X, Y, W;
742        if(g < b) {
743            X = b;
744            Y = g;
745        }
746        else {
747            X = g;
748            Y = b;
749        }
750        if(r < X) {
751            W = r;
752        }
753        else {
754            W = X;
755            X = r;
756        }
757        return X - Math.min(W, Y);
758    }
759
760    /**
761     * Defined as per HSL; normally you only need {@link #channelL(float)} to get accurate lightness for CIELAB. This
762     * ranges from 0.0f (black) to 1.0f (white).
763     *
764     * @param encoded a packed float CIELAB color
765     * @return the lightness of the given color as HSL would calculate it
766     */
767    public static float lightness(final float encoded) {
768        final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
769        final float L = (1f/1.16f)*((decoded & 0xff) / 255f + 0.16f);
770        final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) *  (0.2f / 127.5f);
771        final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.5f / 127.5f);
772        final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A);
773        final float y = reverseXYZ(L);
774        final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B);
775        final float r = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z, 0f), 1f));
776        final float g = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z, 0f), 1f));
777        final float b = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z, 0f), 1f));
778        float X, Y, W;
779        if(g < b) {
780            X = b;
781            Y = g;
782        }
783        else {
784            X = g;
785            Y = b;
786        }
787        if(r < X) {
788            W = r;
789        }
790        else {
791            W = X;
792            X = r;
793        }
794        float d = X - Math.min(W, Y);
795        return X * (1f - 0.5f * d / (X + 1e-10f));
796    }
797
798    /**
799     * Gets the hue of the given encoded color, as a float from 0f (inclusive, red and approaching orange if increased)
800     * to 1f (exclusive, red and approaching purple if decreased).
801     *
802     * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}
803     * @return The hue of the color from 0.0 (red, inclusive) towards orange, then yellow, and
804     * eventually to purple before looping back to almost the same red (1.0, exclusive)
805     */
806    public static float hue(final float encoded) {
807        final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
808        final float L = (1f/1.16f)*((decoded & 0xff) / 255f + 0.16f);
809        final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) *  (0.2f / 127.5f);
810        final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.5f / 127.5f);
811        final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A);
812        final float y = reverseXYZ(L);
813        final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B);
814        final float r = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z, 0f), 1f));
815        final float g = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z, 0f), 1f));
816        final float b = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z, 0f), 1f));
817        float X, Y, Z, W;
818        if(g < b) {
819            X = b;
820            Y = g;
821            Z = -1f;
822            W = 2f / 3f;
823        }
824        else {
825            X = g;
826            Y = b;
827            Z = 0f;
828            W = -1f / 3f;
829        }
830        if(r < X) {
831            Z = W;
832            W = r;
833        }
834        else {
835            W = X;
836            X = r;
837        }
838        float d = X - Math.min(W, Y);
839        return Math.abs(Z + (W - Y) / (6f * d + 1e-10f));
840    }
841    /**
842     * Gets a variation on the packed float color basis as another packed float that has its hue, saturation, lightness,
843     * and opacity adjusted by the specified amounts. Note that this edits the color in HSL space, not CIELAB! Takes
844     * floats representing the amounts of change to apply to hue, saturation, lightness, and opacity; these can be
845     * between -1f and 1f. Returns a float that can be used as a packed or encoded color with methods like
846     * {@link com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.Batch#setPackedColor(float)}. The float is likely to be different than the
847     * result of {@code basis} unless hue, saturation, lightness, and opacity are all 0.
848     * This won't allocate any objects.
849     * <br>
850     * The parameters this takes all specify additive changes for a color component, clamping the final values so they
851     * can't go above 1 or below 0, with an exception for hue, which can rotate around if lower or higher hues would be
852     * used. As an example, if you give this 0.4f for saturation, and the current color has saturation 0.7f, then the
853     * resulting color will have 1f for saturation. If you gave this -0.1f for saturation and the current color again
854     * has saturation 0.7f, then resulting color will have 0.6f for saturation.
855     *
856     * @param basis      a packed float color that will be used as the starting point to make the next color
857     * @param hue        -1f to 1f, the hue change that can be applied to the new float color (not clamped, wraps)
858     * @param saturation -1f to 1f, the saturation change that can be applied to the new float color
859     * @param light      -1f to 1f, the light/brightness change that can be applied to the new float color
860     * @param opacity    -1f to 1f, the opacity/alpha change that can be applied to the new float color
861     * @return a float encoding a variation of basis with the given changes
862     */
863    public static float toEditedFloat(float basis, float hue, float saturation, float light, float opacity) {
864        final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(basis);
865        final float li = Math.min(Math.max(light + (decoded & 0xff) / 255f, 0f), 1f);
866        opacity = Math.min(Math.max(opacity + (decoded >>> 25) * (1f / 127f), 0f), 1f);
867        if (li <= 0.001f)
868            return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat((((int) (opacity * 255f) << 24) & 0xFE000000) | 0x808000);
869        final float L = (1f/1.16f)*(li + 0.16f);
870        final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) *  (0.2f / 127.5f);
871        final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.5f / 127.5f);
872        final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A);
873        final float y = reverseXYZ(L);
874        final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B);
875        final float r = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z, 0f), 1f));
876        final float g = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z, 0f), 1f));
877        final float b = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z, 0f), 1f));
878        float X, Y, Z, W;
879        if(g < b) {
880            X = b;
881            Y = g;
882            Z = -1f;
883            W = 2f / 3f;
884        }
885        else {
886            X = g;
887            Y = b;
888            Z = 0f;
889            W = -1f / 3f;
890        }
891        if(r < X) {
892            Z = W;
893            W = r;
894        }
895        else {
896            W = X;
897            X = r;
898        }
899        final float d = X - Math.min(W, Y);
900        final float lum = X * (1f - 0.5f * d / (X + 1e-10f));
901        hue += Math.abs(Z + (W - Y) / (6f * d + 1e-10f)) + 1f;
902        saturation += (X - lum) / (Math.min(lum, 1f - lum) + 1e-10f);
903        return fromRGBA(FloatColors.hsl2rgb(hue - (int)hue, Math.min(Math.max(saturation, 0f), 1f), lum, opacity));
904    }
905
906
907    /**
908     * Given a packed float CIELAB color, this edits its L, A, B, and alpha channels by adding the corresponding "add"
909     * parameter and then clamping. This returns a different float value (of course, the given float can't be edited
910     * in-place). You can give a value of 0 for any "add" parameter you want to stay unchanged. This clamps the
911     * resulting color so it contains in-range L, A, B, and alpha values, but it doesn't guarantee it stays in-gamut.
912     * @param encoded a packed float CIELAB color
913     * @param addL how much to add to the L channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
914     * @param addA how much to add to the A channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
915     * @param addB how much to add to the B channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
916     * @param addAlpha how much to add to the alpha channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
917     * @return a packed float CIELAB color with the requested edits applied to {@code encoded}
918     */
919    public static float editCIELAB(float encoded, float addL, float addA, float addB, float addAlpha) {
920        return editCIELAB(encoded, addL, addA, addB, addAlpha, 1f, 1f, 1f, 1f);
921    }
922    /**
923     * Given a packed float CIELAB color, this edits its L, A, B, and alpha channels by first multiplying each channel
924     * by the corresponding "mul" parameter and then adding the corresponding "add" parameter, before clamping. This
925     * means the lightness value {@code L} is multiplied by {@code mulL}, then has {@code addL} added, and then is
926     * clamped to the normal range for L (0 to 1). This returns a different float value (of course, the given float
927     * can't be edited in-place). You can give a value of 0 for any "add" parameter you want to stay unchanged, or a
928     * value of 1 for any "mul" parameter that shouldn't change. Note that this manipulates A and B in the -0.5 to 0.5
929     * range, so if you multiply by a small number like {@code 0.25f}, then this will produce a less-saturated color,
930     * and if you multiply by a larger number like {@code 4f}, then you will get a much more-saturated color. This
931     * clamps the resulting color so it contains in-range L, A, B, and alpha values, but it doesn't guarantee it stays
932     * in-gamut.
933     * @param encoded a packed float CIELAB color
934     * @param addL how much to add to the L channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
935     * @param addA how much to add to the A channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
936     * @param addB how much to add to the B channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
937     * @param addAlpha how much to add to the alpha channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
938     * @param mulL how much to multiply the L channel by; should be non-negative
939     * @param mulA how much to multiply the A channel by; usually non-negative (not always)
940     * @param mulB how much to multiply the B channel by; usually non-negative (not always)
941     * @param mulAlpha how much to multiply the alpha channel by; should be non-negative
942     * @return a packed float CIELAB color with the requested edits applied to {@code encoded}
943     */
944    public static float editCIELAB(float encoded, float addL, float addA, float addB, float addAlpha,
945                                  float mulL, float mulA, float mulB, float mulAlpha) {
946        final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
947        float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
948        float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f)  * (0.2f / 127.5f);
949        float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.5f / 127.5f);
950        float alpha = (decoded >>> 25) / 127f;
951
952        L = Math.min(Math.max(L * mulL + addL, 0f), 1f);
953        A = Math.min(Math.max(A * mulA + addA * 2f, -1f), 1f) * 0.5f;
954        B = Math.min(Math.max(B * mulB + addB * 2f, -1f), 1f) * 0.5f;
955        alpha = Math.min(Math.max(alpha * mulAlpha + addAlpha, 0f), 1f);
956        return clamp(L, A, B, alpha);
957    }
958
959    /**
960     * The "L" channel of the given packed float in CIELAB format, which is its lightness; ranges from 0.0f to
961     * 1.0f . You can edit the L of a color with {@link #lighten(float, float)} and {@link #darken(float, float)}.
962     *
963     * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}
964     * @return the L value as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
965     */
966    public static float channelL(final float encoded)
967    {
968        return (NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xff) / 255f;
969    }
970
971    /**
972     * The "A" channel of the given packed float in CIELAB format, which when combined with the B channel describes the
973     * hue and saturation of a color; ranges from 0f to 1f . If A is 0f, the color will be cooler, more green or
974     * blue; if A is 1f, the color will be warmer, from magenta to orange. You can edit the A of a color with
975     * {@link #raiseA(float, float)} and {@link #lowerA(float, float)}.
976     * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}
977     * @return the A value as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
978     */
979    public static float channelA(final float encoded)
980    {
981        return ((NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) >>> 8 & 0xff)) / 255f;
982    }
983
984    /**
985     * The "B" channel of the given packed float in CIELAB format, which when combined with the A channel describes the
986     * hue and saturation of a color; ranges from 0f to 1f . If B is 0f, the color will be more "artificial", more
987     * blue or purple; if B is 1f, the color will be more "natural", from green to yellow to orange. You can edit
988     * the B of a color with {@link #raiseB(float, float)} and {@link #lowerB(float, float)}.
989     * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}
990     * @return the B value as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
991     */
992    public static float channelB(final float encoded)
993    {
994        return ((NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) >>> 16 & 0xff)) / 255f;
995    }
996
997    /**
998     * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards white by change. While change should be between 0f (return
999     * start as-is) and 1f (return white), start should be a packed color, as from
1000     * {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
1001     * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp
1002     * towards white. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and both
1003     * chroma of start as-is.
1004     * @see #darken(float, float) the counterpart method that darkens a float color
1005     * @param start the starting color as a packed float
1006     * @param change how much to go from start toward white, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to white
1007     * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and white
1008     */
1009    public static float lighten(final float start, final float change) {
1010        final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), i = s & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFFFF00;
1011        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (i + (0xFF - i) * change) & 0xFF) | other);
1012    }
1013
1014    /**
1015     * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards black by change. While change should be between 0f (return
1016     * start as-is) and 1f (return black), start should be a packed color, as from
1017     * {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
1018     * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp
1019     * towards black. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and both
1020     * chroma of start as-is.
1021     * @see #lighten(float, float) the counterpart method that lightens a float color
1022     * @param start the starting color as a packed float
1023     * @param change how much to go from start toward black, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to black
1024     * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and black
1025     */
1026    public static float darken(final float start, final float change) {
1027        final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), i = s & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFFFF00;
1028        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (i * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) | other);
1029    }
1030
1031    /**
1032     * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a warmer color (orange to magenta) by change. While change
1033     * should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully warmed), start should be a packed color, as from
1034     * {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors,
1035     * and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to
1036     * lerp towards a warmer color. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the
1037     * alpha and L of start as-is.
1038     * @see #lowerA(float, float) the counterpart method that cools a float color
1039     * @param start the starting color as a packed float
1040     * @param change how much to warm start, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a warmer result
1041     * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a warmer color
1042     */
1043    public static float raiseA(final float start, final float change) {
1044        final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), p = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFF00FF;
1045        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (p + (0xFF - p) * change) << 8 & 0xFF00) | other);
1046    }
1047
1048    /**
1049     * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a cooler color (green to blue) by change. While change
1050     * should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully cooled), start should be a packed color, as from
1051     * {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
1052     * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp
1053     * towards a cooler color. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and
1054     * L of start as-is.
1055     * @see #raiseA(float, float) the counterpart method that warms a float color
1056     * @param start the starting color as a packed float
1057     * @param change how much to cool start, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a cooler result
1058     * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a cooler color
1059     */
1060    public static float lowerA(final float start, final float change) {
1061        final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), p = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFF00FF;
1062        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (p * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) << 8 | other);
1063    }
1064
1065    /**
1066     * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a "natural" color (between green and orange) by change.
1067     * While change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully natural), start should be a packed
1068     * color, as from {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary
1069     * Colors, and is a little more efficient and clear than using
1070     * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards a more natural color. Unlike
1071     * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and L of start as-is.
1072     * @see #lowerB(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less natural
1073     * @param start the starting color as a packed float
1074     * @param change how much to change start to a natural color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a more natural result
1075     * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a more natural color
1076     */
1077    public static float raiseB(final float start, final float change) {
1078        final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), t = s >>> 16 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFE00FFFF;
1079        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (t + (0xFF - t) * change) << 16 & 0xFF0000) | other);
1080    }
1081
1082    /**
1083     * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards an "artificial" color (between blue and purple) by change.
1084     * While change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully artificial), start should be a packed
1085     * color, as from {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary
1086     * Colors, and is a little more efficient and clear than using
1087     * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards a more artificial color. Unlike
1088     * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and L of start as-is.
1089     * @see #raiseB(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less artificial
1090     * @param start the starting color as a packed float
1091     * @param change how much to change start to a bolder color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a more artificial result
1092     * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a more artificial color
1093     */
1094    public static float lowerB(final float start, final float change) {
1095        final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), t = s >>> 16 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFE00FFFF;
1096        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (t * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) << 16 | other);
1097    }
1098
1099    /**
1100     * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards that color made opaque by change. While change should be
1101     * between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return start with full alpha), start should be a packed color, as from
1102     * {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
1103     * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp
1104     * towards transparent. This won't change the L, A, or B of the color.
1105     * @see #fade(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more translucent
1106     * @param start the starting color as a packed float
1107     * @param change how much to go from start toward opaque, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to opaque
1108     * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and its opaque version
1109     */
1110    public static float blot(final float start, final float change) {
1111        final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), opacity = s >>> 24 & 0xFE, other = s & 0x00FFFFFF;
1112        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (opacity + (0xFE - opacity) * change) & 0xFE) << 24 | other);
1113    }
1114
1115    /**
1116     * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards transparent by change. While change should be between 0
1117     * (return start as-is) and 1f (return the color with 0 alpha), start should be a packed color, as from
1118     * {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors,
1119     * and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to
1120     * lerp towards transparent. This won't change the L, A, or B of the color.
1121     * @see #blot(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more opaque
1122     * @param start the starting color as a packed float
1123     * @param change how much to go from start toward transparent, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to transparent
1124     * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and transparent
1125     */
1126    public static float fade(final float start, final float change) {
1127        final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), opacity = s & 0xFE, other = s & 0x00FFFFFF;
1128        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (opacity * (1f - change)) & 0xFE) << 24 | other);
1129    }
1130
1131    /**
1132     * Brings the chromatic components of {@code start} closer to grayscale by {@code change} (desaturating them). While
1133     * change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully gray), start should be a packed color, as
1134     * from {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}. This only changes A and B; it leaves L and alpha alone.
1135     * @see #enrich(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more saturated
1136     * @param start the starting color as a packed float
1137     * @param change how much to change start to a desaturated color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a less saturated result
1138     * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a desaturated color
1139     */
1140    public static float dullen(final float start, final float change) {
1141        final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start);
1142        return cielab((s & 0xFF) / 255f,
1143                ((s >>> 8 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f - change) + 0.5f,
1144                ((s >>> 16 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f - change) + 0.5f,
1145                (s >>> 25) / 127f);
1146    }
1147
1148    /**
1149     * Pushes the chromatic components of {@code start} away from grayscale by change (saturating them). While change
1150     * should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return maximally saturated), start should be a packed color, as
1151     * from {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}. This changes only A and B. This prevents high values for change
1152     * from pushing A or B out of the valid range by using {@link #clamp(float, float, float, float)}; this doesn't
1153     * actually keep the color in-gamut, but usually rendering code can handle out-of-gamut colors in some way.
1154     * Alpha. The alpha never changes. It never changes L either.
1155     * @see #dullen(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less saturated
1156     * @param start the starting color as a packed float
1157     * @param change how much to change start to a saturated color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a more saturated result
1158     * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a saturated color
1159     */
1160    public static float enrich(final float start, final float change) {
1161        final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start);
1162        return clamp((s & 0xFF) / 255f,
1163                ((s >>> 8 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f + change) + 0.5f,
1164                ((s >>> 16 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f + change) + 0.5f,
1165                (s >>> 25) / 127f);
1166    }
1167
1168    /**
1169     * Given a packed float CIELAB color {@code mainColor} and another CIELAB color that it should be made to contrast with,
1170     * gets a packed float CIELAB color with roughly inverted lightness but the same chromatic channels and opacity (A and B
1171     * are likely to be clamped if the result gets close to white or black). This won't ever produce black or other very
1172     * dark colors, and also has a gap in the range it produces for intensity values between 0.5 and 0.55. That allows
1173     * most of the colors this method produces to contrast well as a foreground when displayed on a background of
1174     * {@code contrastingColor}, or vice versa. This will leave the lightness unchanged if the chromatic channels of the
1175     * contrastingColor and those of the mainColor are already very different. This has nothing to do with the contrast
1176     * channel of the tweak in ColorfulBatch; where that part of the tweak can make too-similar lightness values further
1177     * apart by just a little, this makes a modification on {@code mainColor} to maximize its lightness difference from
1178     * {@code contrastingColor} without losing its other qualities.
1179     * @param mainColor a packed float color, as produced by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}; this is the color that will be adjusted
1180     * @param contrastingColor a packed float color, as produced by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}; the adjusted mainColor will contrast with this
1181     * @return a different CIELAB packed float color, based on mainColor but with potentially very different lightness
1182     */
1183    public static float inverseLightness(final float mainColor, final float contrastingColor)
1184    {
1185        final int bits = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor),
1186                contrastBits = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(contrastingColor),
1187                L = (bits & 0xff),
1188                A = (bits >>> 8 & 0xff),
1189                B = (bits >>> 16 & 0xff),
1190                cL = (contrastBits & 0xff),
1191                cA = (contrastBits >>> 8 & 0xff),
1192                cB = (contrastBits >>> 16 & 0xff);
1193        if((A - cA) * (A - cA) + (B - cB) * (B - cB) >= 0x10000)
1194            return mainColor;
1195        return cielab(cL < 128 ? L * (0.45f / 255f) + 0.5f : 0.5f - L * (0.45f / 255f), A / 255f, B / 255f, 0x1.0p-8f * (bits >>> 24));
1196    }
1197
1198    /**
1199     * Given a packed float CIELAB color {@code mainColor} and another CIELAB color that it should be made to contrast
1200     * with, gets a packed float CIELAB color with L that should be quite different from {@code contrastingColor}'s L,
1201     * but the same chromatic channels and opacity (A and B are likely to be clamped if the result gets close to white
1202     * or black). This allows most of the colors this method produces to contrast well as a foreground when displayed on
1203     * a background of {@code contrastingColor}, or vice versa.
1204     * <br>
1205     * This is similar to {@link #inverseLightness(float, float)}, but is considerably simpler, and this method will
1206     * change the lightness of mainColor when the two given colors have close lightness but distant chroma. Because it
1207     * averages the original L of mainColor with the modified one, this tends to not produce harsh color changes.
1208     * @param mainColor a packed CIELAB float color; this is the color that will be adjusted
1209     * @param contrastingColor a packed CIELAB float color; the adjusted mainColor will contrast with the L of this
1210     * @return a different packed CIELAB float color, based on mainColor but typically with different lightness
1211     */
1212    public static float differentiateLightness(final float mainColor, final float contrastingColor)
1213    {
1214        final int main = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor), contrast = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(contrastingColor);
1215        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat((main & 0xFEFFFF00) | (contrast + 128 & 0xFF) + (main & 0xFF) >>> 1);
1216    }
1217
1218    /**
1219     * Pretty simple; adds 0.5 to the given color's L and wraps it around if it would go above 1.0, then averages that
1220     * with the original L. This means light colors become darker, and dark colors become lighter, with almost all
1221     * results in the middle-range of possible lightness.
1222     * @param mainColor a packed CIELAB float color
1223     * @return a different packed CIELAB float color, with its L channel changed and limited to the correct gamut
1224     */
