1225    public static float offsetLightness(final float mainColor) {
1226        final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor);
1227        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat((decoded & 0xFEFFFF00) | (decoded + 128 & 0xFF) + (decoded & 0xFF) >>> 1);
1228    }
1229
1230    /**
1231     * Makes the additive CIELAB color stored in {@code color} cause less of a change when used as a tint, as if it were
1232     * mixed with neutral gray. When {@code fraction} is 1.0, this returns color unchanged; when fraction is 0.0, it
1233     * returns {@link Palette#GRAY}, and when it is in-between 0.0 and 1.0 it returns something between the two. This is
1234     * meant for things like area of effect abilities that make smaller color changes toward their periphery.
1235     * @param color a color that should have its tinting effect potentially weakened
1236     * @param fraction how much of {@code color} should be kept, from 0.0 to 1.0
1237     * @return a CIELAB float color between gray and {@code color}
1238     */
1239    public static float lessenChange(final float color, float fraction) {
1240        final int e = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(color),
1241                sL = 0x80, sA = 0x80, sB = 0x80,
1242                eL = (e & 0xFF), eA = (e >>> 8) & 0xFF, eB = (e >>> 16) & 0xFF, eAlpha = e >>> 24 & 0xFE;
1243        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (sL + fraction * (eL - sL)) & 0xFF)
1244                | (((int) (sA + fraction * (eA - sA)) & 0xFF) << 8)
1245                | (((int) (sB + fraction * (eB - sB)) & 0xFF) << 16)
1246                | (eAlpha << 24));
1247    }
1248
1249    /**
1250     * Returns true if the given packed float color, as CIELAB, is valid to convert losslessly back to RGBA.
1251     * @param packed a packed float color as CIELAB
1252     * @return true if the given packed float color can be converted back and forth to RGBA
1253     */
1254    public static boolean inGamut(final float packed)
1255    {
1256        final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
1257        final float L = (1f/1.16f)*((decoded & 0xff) / 255f + 0.16f);
1258        final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) *  (0.2f / 127.5f);
1259        final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.5f / 127.5f);
1260        final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A);
1261        final float y = reverseXYZ(L);
1262        final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B);
1263        final float r = +3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z;
1264        if(r <= -0x1p-8f || r >= 0x1.01p0f) return false;
1265        final float g = -0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z;
1266        if(g <= -0x1p-8f || g >= 0x1.01p0f) return false;
1267        final float b = +0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z;
1268        return (b > -0x1p-8f && b < 0x1.01p0f);
1269
1270//        final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
1271//        final float L = (1f/1.16f)*((decoded & 0xff) / 255f + 0.16f);
1272//        final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) *  (0.2f / 127.5f);
1273//        final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.5f / 127.5f);
1274//        final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A);
1275//        final float y = reverseXYZ(L);
1276//        final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B);
1277//        boolean ret = true;
1278//        final float r = +3.2406f * x + -1.5372f * y + -0.4986f * z;
1279////        final float r = +3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z;
1280//        if(r <= -0x1p-8f || r >= 0x1.01p0f) ret = false;
1281////        final float g = -0.9689f * x + +1.8758f * y + +0.0415f * z;
1282//        final float g = -0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z;
1283//        if(g <= -0x1p-8f || g >= 0x1.01p0f) ret = false;
1284////        final float b = +0.0557f * x + -0.2040f * y + +1.0570f * z;
1285//        final float b = +0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z;
1286//        ret &= (b > -0x1p-8f && b < 0x1.01p0f);
1287//        if(!ret) System.out.printf("L %f, A %f, B %f, x %f, y %f, z %f, r %f, g %f, b %f\n", L, A, B,  x, y, z,  r, g, b);
1288//        return ret;
1289
1290    }
1291
1292    /**
1293     * Returns true if the given CIELAB values are valid to convert losslessly back to RGBA.
1294     * @param L lightness, as a float from 0 to 1
1295     * @param A cyan-to-red chroma, as a float from 0 to 1
1296     * @param B blue-to-yellow chroma, as a float from 0 to 1
1297     * @return true if the given packed float color can be converted back and forth to RGBA
1298     */
1299    public static boolean inGamut(float L, float A, float B)
1300    {
1301        L = (1f/1.16f)*(L + 0.16f);
1302        A = (A - 0.5f) * (0.4f);
1303        B = (B - 0.5f);
1304        final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A);
1305        final float y = reverseXYZ(L);
1306        final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B);
1307        final float r = +3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z;
1308        if(r < 0f || r > 1.0f) return false;
1309        final float g = -0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z;
1310        if(g < 0f || g > 1.0f) return false;
1311        final float b = +0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z;
1312        return (b >= 0f && b <= 1.0f);
1313    }
1314
1315    /**
1316     * Iteratively checks whether the given CIELAB color is in-gamut, and either brings the color closer to grayscale if
1317     * it isn't in-gamut, or returns it as soon as it is in-gamut. Maintains the L of the color, only bringing A and B
1318     * closer to grayscale. Note that this version of limitToGamut() is much slower than Oklab's version, because Oklab
1319     * stores its entire gamut as a large constant, while this has to calculate it.
1320     * @param packed a packed float color in CIELAB format; often this color is not in-gamut
1321     * @return the first color this finds that is between the given CIELAB color and grayscale, and is in-gamut
1322     * @see #inGamut(float) You can use inGamut() if you just want to check whether a color is in-gamut.
1323     */
1324    public static float limitToGamut(final float packed) {
1325        final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
1326        final float L = (1f/1.16f)*((decoded & 0xff) / 255f + 0.16f);
1327        final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) *  (0.2f / 127.5f);
1328        final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.5f / 127.5f);
1329        final float y = reverseXYZ(L);
1330        float A2 = A, B2 = B;
1331        for (int attempt = 127; attempt >= 0; attempt--) {
1332            final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A2);
1333            final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B2);
1334            final float r = reverseGamma(+3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z);
1335            final float g = reverseGamma(-0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z);
1336            final float b = reverseGamma(+0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z);
1337            if(r >= 0f && r <= 1f && g >= 0f && g <= 1f && b >= 0f && b <= 1f)
1338                break;
1339            final float progress = attempt * 0x1p-7f;
1340            A2 = (A * progress);
1341            B2 = (B * progress);
1342        }
1343        return cielab(L, A2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, B2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, (decoded >>> 25) / 127f);
1344    }
1345
1346    /**
1347     * Iteratively checks whether the given CIELAB color is in-gamut, and either brings the color closer to grayscale if it
1348     * isn't in-gamut, or returns it as soon as it is in-gamut. Maintains the L of the color, only bringing A and B
1349     * closer to grayscale. This always produces an opaque color.
1350     * @param L lightness; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1351     * @param A cyan-to-red chroma; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1352     * @param B blue-to-yellow chroma; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1353     * @return the first color this finds that is between the given CIELAB color and grayscale, and is in-gamut
1354     * @see #inGamut(float, float, float)  You can use inGamut() if you just want to check whether a color is in-gamut.
1355     */
1356    public static float limitToGamut(float L, float A, float B) {
1357        return limitToGamut(L, A, B, 1f);
1358    }
1359    /**
1360     * Iteratively checks whether the given CIELAB color is in-gamut, and either brings the color closer to grayscale if it
1361     * isn't in-gamut, or returns it as soon as it is in-gamut. Note that this version of limitToGamut() is much slower
1362     * than Oklab's version, because Oklab stores its entire gamut as a large constant, while this has to calculate it.
1363     * @param L lightness; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1364     * @param A cyan-to-red chroma; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1365     * @param B blue-to-yellow chroma; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1366     * @param alpha opacity; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1367     * @return the first color this finds that is between the given CIELAB color and grayscale, and is in-gamut
1368     * @see #inGamut(float, float, float)  You can use inGamut() if you just want to check whether a color is in-gamut.
1369     */
1370    public static float limitToGamut(float L, float A, float B, float alpha) {
1371
1372        L = (1f/1.16f)*(Math.min(Math.max(L, 0f), 1f) + 0.16f);
1373        A = (Math.min(Math.max(A, 0f), 1f) - 0.5f) * 0.4f;
1374        B = (Math.min(Math.max(B, 0f), 1f) - 0.5f);
1375        alpha = Math.min(Math.max(alpha, 0f), 1f);
1376
1377        final float y = reverseXYZ(L);
1378        float A2 = A, B2 = B;
1379        for (int attempt = 127; attempt >= 0; attempt--) {
1380            final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A2);
1381            final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B2);
1382            final float r = reverseGamma(+3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z);
1383            final float g = reverseGamma(-0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z);
1384            final float b = reverseGamma(+0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z);
1385            if(r >= 0f && r <= 1f && g >= 0f && g <= 1f && b >= 0f && b <= 1f)
1386                break;
1387            final float progress = attempt * 0x1p-7f;
1388            A2 = (A * progress);
1389            B2 = (B * progress);
1390        }
1391        return cielab(L, A2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, B2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, alpha);
1392    }
1393
1394    /**
1395     * Makes a quasi-randomly-edited variant on the given {@code color}, allowing typically a small amount of
1396     * {@code variance} (such as 0.05 to 0.25) between the given color and what this can return. The {@code seed} should
1397     * be different each time this is called, and can be obtained from a random number generator to make the colors more
1398     * random, or can be incremented on each call. If the seed is only incremented or decremented, then this shouldn't
1399     * produce two similar colors in a row unless variance is very small. The variance affects the L, A, and B of the
1400     * generated color, and each of those channels can go up or down by the given variance as long as the total distance
1401     * isn't greater than the variance (this considers A and B extra-wide, going from -1 to 1, while L goes from 0 to 1,
1402     * but only internally for measuring distance).
1403     * @param color a packed float color, as produced by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}
1404     * @param seed a long seed that should be different on each call; should not be 0
1405     * @param variance max amount of difference between the given color and the generated color; always less than 1
1406     * @return a generated packed float color that should be at least somewhat different from {@code color}
1407     */
1408    public static float randomEdit(final float color, long seed, final float variance) {
1409        final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(color);
1410        final float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
1411        final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) *  (0.2f / 127.5f);
1412        final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.5f / 127.5f);
1413        final float limit = variance * variance;
1414        float dist, x, y, z;
1415        for (int j = 0; j < 50; j++) {
1416            x = (((seed * 0xD1B54A32D192ED03L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
1417            y = (((seed * 0xABC98388FB8FAC03L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
1418            z = (((seed * 0x8CB92BA72F3D8DD7L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
1419            seed += 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L;
1420            dist = x * x + y * y + z * z;
1421            if(dist <= limit)
1422                return clamp(x + L, (A + y) * 0.5f + 0.5f, (B + z) * 0.5f + 0.5f, (decoded >>> 25) / 127f);
1423        }
1424        return color;
1425    }
1426
1427    /**
1428     * Produces a random packed float color that is always in-gamut and should be uniformly distributed.
1429     * @param random a Random object (preferably a subclass of Random, like {@link com.badlogic.gdx.math.RandomXS128})
1430     * @return a packed float color that is always in-gamut
1431     */
1432    public static float randomColor(Random random) {
1433        float L = random.nextFloat();
1434        float A = random.nextFloat();
1435        float B = random.nextFloat();
1436        while (!inGamut(L, A, B)) {
1437            L = random.nextFloat();
1438            A = random.nextFloat();
1439            B = random.nextFloat();
1440        }
1441        return cielab(L, A, B, 1f);
1442    }
1443
1444}
